These <FI>are<Fi> also proverbs of Solomon, which the men of Hezekiah king of Judah copied out.<CM>
<FI>It is<Fi> the glory of God to conceal a thing: but the honour of kings <FI>is<Fi> to search out a matter.
The heaven for height, and the earth for depth, and the heart of kings <FI>is<Fi> unsearchable.<RF>is…: Heb. there is no searching<Rf><CM>
Take away the dross from the silver, and there shall come forth a vessel for the finer.
Take away the wicked <FI>from<Fi> before the king, and his throne shall be established in righteousness.<CM>
Put not forth thyself in the presence of the king, and stand not in the place of great <FI>men<Fi>:<RF>Put…: Heb. Set not out thy glory<Rf>
For better <FI>it is<Fi> that it be said unto thee, Come up hither; than that thou shouldest be put lower in the presence of the prince whom thine eyes have seen.<CM>
Go not forth hastily to strive, lest <FI>thou know not<Fi> what to do in the end thereof, when thy neighbour hath put thee to shame.
Debate thy cause with thy neighbour <FI>himself<Fi>; and discover not a secret to another:<RF>a secret…: or, the secret of<Rf>
Lest he that heareth <FI>it<Fi> put thee to shame, and thine infamy turn not away.<CM>
A word fitly spoken <FI>is like<Fi> apples of gold in pictures of silver.<RF>fitly…: Heb. spoken upon his wheels<Rf>
<FI>As<Fi> an earring of gold, and an ornament of fine gold, <FI>so is<Fi> a wise reprover upon an obedient ear.<CM>
As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, <FI>so is<Fi> a faithful messenger to them that send him: for he refresheth the soul of his masters.<CM>
Whoso boasteth himself of a false gift <FI>is like<Fi> clouds and wind without rain.<RF>of a…: Heb. in a gift of falsehood<Rf><CM>
By long forbearing is a prince persuaded, and a soft tongue breaketh the bone.<CM>
Hast thou found honey? eat so much as is sufficient for thee, lest thou be filled therewith, and vomit it.<CM>
Withdraw thy foot from thy neighbour's house; lest he be weary of thee, and <FI>so<Fi> hate thee.<RF>Withdraw…: or, Let thy foot be seldom in<Rf><RF>weary…: Heb. full of thee<Rf><CM>
A man that beareth false witness against his neighbour <FI>is<Fi> a maul, and a sword, and a sharp arrow.<CM>
Confidence in an unfaithful man in time of trouble <FI>is like<Fi> a broken tooth, and a foot out of joint.<CM>
<FI>As<Fi> he that taketh away a garment in cold weather, <FI>and as<Fi> vinegar upon nitre, so <FI>is<Fi> he that singeth songs to an heavy heart.<CM>
If thine enemy be hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he be thirsty, give him water to drink:
For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the LORD shall reward thee.<CM>
The north wind driveth away rain: so <FI>doth<Fi> an angry countenance a backbiting tongue.<RF>driveth…: or, bringeth forth rain: so doth a backbiting tongue an angry countenance<Rf><CM>
<FI>It is<Fi> better to dwell in the corner of the housetop, than with a brawling woman and in a wide house.<CM>
<FI>As<Fi> cold waters to a thirsty soul, so <FI>is<Fi> good news from a far country.<CM>
A righteous man falling down before the wicked <FI>is as<Fi> a troubled fountain, and a corrupt spring.<CM>
<FI>It is<Fi> not good to eat much honey: so <FI>for men<Fi> to search their own glory <FI>is not<Fi> glory.<CM>
He that <FI>hath<Fi> no rule over his own spirit <FI>is like<Fi> a city <FI>that is<Fi> broken down, <FI>and<Fi> without walls.<CM>
